RDC: l'armée annonce des opérations de «grande envergure» à Beni
02 Nov 2019, 00:54 by RFI

Les Forces armées de la RDC ont annoncé qu’elles ont lancé depuis mercredi les opérations dites de « grande envergure » contre les groupes armés locaux et étrangers actifs dans l’est du pays. À travers cette initiative, elles espèrent mettre fin définitivement à l’insécurité dans cette région fragilisée par des années de conflits armés.

Le gouvernement annonce avoir quasiment doublé l’effectif de l’armée dans la région. On compterait aujourd’hui environ 21 000 soldats à Beni contre près de 11 000 précédemment, soit un dixième de l’effectif des FARDC.
Selon une source militaire, les troupes ayant passé plus de temps dans cette partie du pays seront progressivement relevées. C’était l’un des problèmes soulevés par la société civile, le maintien de contingents fatigués après des mois, voire des années d’opérations ou d’attente dans les forêts du territoire de Beni.
L’armée parle également d’une plus grande implication de son état-major général. Le président Félix Tshisekedi avait promis de transférer là-bas l’état-major. Son chef, le général d’armée Célestin Mbala, se retrouve actuellement dans la région, tout comme le commandant de la 3e zone de défense des FARDC, le général Fall Sikabwe, affecté à Kisangani. Reste à savoir combien de temps ils vont rester, s’interroge un député.
L’un des problèmes récurrents de l’armée à Beni, c’était la logistique, avec des militaires qui signalaient parfois des ruptures d’approvisionnement. Les FARDC soutiennent avoir renforcé leurs capacités dans ce domaine. Une source militaire parle même d’un renfort dans le domaine aérien.
La société civile de Beni dit attendre pour se prononcer, elle dit attendre des actes concrets, échaudés par de précédents effets d’annonce. Il faut dire que, plus d’une fois, l’armée congolaise a réussi à prendre les positions attribuées à de présumés rebelles ougandais ADF avant de les perdre.
Ces opérations sont une initiative unilatérale de l’armée congolaise, la Monusco n’a pas été sollicitée ou associée. Toutefois, la mission onusienne promet son appui si elle est sollicitée et plaide pour le respect des droits de l‘homme et la protection des populations civiles au cours de ces opérations.

Is the club from the Emirates in the KHL a reality?
02 Nov 2019 by Samir Arar
What the KHL Vice President forgot in this country. Someone will be surprised, but there is hockey in the Emirates. From October 29 to October 31, the tournament called The Open Cup Emirates Hockey league was held at The Dubai Mall. And this tournament would be ordinary, if not for one circumstance. The tournament was attended by KHL vice president of hockey operations Georgy Kobylyansky. In 2019, information appeared that the club from the UAE wants to join the league by 2021. Vice President at the games. Does league management probe the ground? In 2018, Alexander Medvedev was the first to mention the creation of a team in this country. "Serious people are in the UAE. If they conceived something, then the monetary factor will not stop them." Immediately Kobylyansky denied this information. Having said that you should not take the creation of this team seriously, paying attention to options with France and the UK. According to the development strategy of the KHL until 2021, there must be 10 foreign teams in the league. Today they are half as much. Due to financial problems, our Bratislava “Slovan” left our league. Everyone quickly forgot about this development strategy when they adopted a new one until 2023. It now says that the KHL is working to expand its geography and attract new clubs to the League. That is, the emergence of new clubs is possible, but not in the same quantity as previously planned. What do the Emirates attract with the KHL?



There are several factors here. Firstly, it is the city of Dubai itself. The city is a tourist center. Our league will have its own version of Vegas. Also in Dubai there is an arena for 17 thousand people. But there are no pipes laid that will provide ice freezing. According to the head of the hockey league of the Emirates, pipes will be laid next summer. Negotiations with the construction company are underway, but it will be necessary to temporarily close the arena for work. Secondly, the majority of the population of Dubai are migrants. A huge number of Russians, Europeans and North Americans who are familiar with this game. There are about 50 thousand Russians in the UAE. Thirdly, they want to include hotels in the project. In the price they want to include tickets for the games of the local team. Fourth, financial stability. The complete lack of public investment. If local sheikhs join the project, the finance team will become almost the richest. Also in the UAE there is no tax on personal income, business income and salaries. Russian relations with the UAE have now reached a new level. Recently, the heads of Russia and the Emirates exchanged gifts. Expect deterioration in relations, as with the same UK, is not worth it. It is precisely because of this, by the way, that we did not see the club from the islands. From a commercial point of view, this is exactly what the KHL presents itself to be a good option. The main disadvantage is the lack of local players. Hockey there is a subculture that is trying to reach the masses. Play in the new team, if it is created, will be Europeans and North Americans. Is it necessary for the league to create a second “Kunlun” - the question is. In the Emirates there is a popular hockey team - “Dubai Mighty Cameles”, they have 34.3 thousand Instagram followers. For comparison, this is more than Kunlun’s - 12.8 thousand, Sochi - 25.9 thousand, Vityaz - 14.7 thousand, Dynamo Minsk - 21.5 thousand, Neftekhimik - 1 , 7 thousand and "Torpedo" - 30.3 thousand.



“You make an elephant out of a fly” Is the club from the Emirates in the KHL real? In search of an answer to this question, we decided to turn to the head of the local league, Vladimir Burdun. Questions were asked: "Are negotiations going on between the league and the team now? And what did the KHL vice president for hockey operations forget in the midst of the season in Dubai?" The head of the Emirates league replied: “You are making an elephant out of a fly. Georgy Valerievich was just resting here. He came at my invitation.” Rest? In the midst of the season? I think the KHL vice president has plenty of work right now. But you can see the infrastructure. Declare a year ago about the possibility of joining a hockey league team from the UAE and just fly to "rest"? I don’t really believe it.
